Award.AwardTitle: The Second Workshop on Measuring Precise Radial Velocities
Award.AbstractNarration: This award funds travel support and stipends for 21 participants, mainly early-career researchers, to attend "The Second Workshop on Measuring Precise Radial Velocities," which will take place July 6-8, 2015 at Yale University, New Haven, CT. The workshop will provide a unique opportunity to gather scientists with a broad range of specialized expertise to reflect on both the big picture and the details at every level of searches for extrasolar planets using the Doppler Radial Velocity technique. Succeeding in this effort will require significant improvements to spectrometer capabilities in order to detect the very small gravitational pulls of such small planets on their host stars. The workshop will document the established state of the art Doppler precision from various facilities, assess different spectrometer designs and the scientific analysis for recent results, and discuss methods for assessing the statistical significance of weak detections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The second workshop on Extreme Precision Radial Velocities was held at Yale University, New Haven CT from July 6 – 8, 2015. We held primer sessions on Sunday July 5th, 2015 to introduce students and researchers who are new to the field to critical concepts surrounding high precision challenges and analysis tools so that they could get the most out of the workshop meetings.  More than 150 researchers attended this meeting and about 75% of the attendees were students or postdoctoral fellows. 

The workshop focused on instrumentation (Monday), statistical analysis tools and techniques for distinguishing photospheric velocities from the orbital motion of the star (Tuesday) and the path toward higher precision RV measurements (Wednesday). Researchers from major Doppler survey programs presented a summary of their current precision and showed that the state of the art precision is 1 m/s (a factor of ten less than we need to detect Earth analogs around other stars).  In preparation for the meeting, a double-blind study was carried out: the astronomical community was given a radial velocity data set with simulated planets in the presence of time-correlated noise and asked to use their software analysis tools to recover the planets. The results of this study were presented at the meeting and showed that without fail, the community could not reliably detect signals with velocity amplitudes smaller than 1 m/s (presented in a publication by Dumusque et al 2016, in prep).

The conclusions from the workshop were that higher resolution instruments with more stability (temperature and pressure) were required to improve our instrumental precision. New statistical analysis techniques were presented and discussed, which offer significant improvement in our ability address time-correlated noise in our data. And details about the barycentric velocity correction, elimination of telluric contamination, modal noise in fibers, and new wavelength calibration techniques were discussed. For the foreseeable future, extreme precision radial velocity measurements are the best way to detect small rocky planets orbiting nearby stars.

The workshop served to educate emerging researchers about the critical challenges for high precision radial velocity measurements. All of the plenary talks were recorded (http://eprv.astro.yale.edu) and a summary paper was written (Fischer et al. 2016) to capture the state of the art in precision velocity measurements and approaches for reaching 10 cm/s precision.
